Task 3
# Exploratory Data Analysis

In this section, I explore three indicators from the WDI dataset:
- GDP per capita
- Life expectancy
- Inflation rate

```{python}
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("wdi.csv")

# quick check
df.shape, df.columns
```


## Indicator 1: GDP per Capita

GDP per capita measures economic output per person and is a common proxy for living standards.

```{python}

# summary stats
df["gdp_per_capita"].describe()
```

```{python}

# histogram
df["gdp_per_capita"].plot(kind="hist", bins=30, title="GDP per Capita Distribution")
```

**Findings**
- The spread of the histogram is very narrow, with manny countries close to 0
- Right skew, as there are a few countries with very high GDP per Capital Distribution
- There are 2 noticable outliers


## Indicator 2: Life Expectancy

Life expectancy reflects overall health outcomes and quality of life.

```{python}
# summary stats
df["life_expectancy"].describe()
```

```{python}
# histogram
df["life_expectancy"].plot(kind="hist", bins=30, title="Life Expectancy Distribution")
```

**Findings**
- The range seems to be very clustered around 70-80 years
- More variability compared to GDP per capita
- One clear outlier at 20 years


## Indicator 3: Inflation Rate

Inflation rate measures changes in price levels and can reflect macroeconomic stability.

```{python}
# summary stats
df["inflation_rate"].describe()
```

```{python}
# boxplot
df[["inflation_rate"]].plot(kind="box", title="Inflation Rate (Boxplot)")
```

**Findings**
- Inflation rates have extreme outliers from high-inflation countries
- Most observations seem to be high at the 25-50% range
- This shows that most countries are not economically stable

Task 4
## Figure: GDP per capita vs Life expectancy

```{python}
# label: fig-gdp-life
# fig-cap: "GDP per capita vs life expectancy. Source: World Bank WDI (see References)."
# fig-alt: "Scatter plot of GDP per capita vs life expectancy"

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

df = pd.read_csv("wdi.csv")

plt.figure()
plt.scatter(df["life_expectancy"], df["gdp_per_capita"])
plt.title("GDP per Capita vs Life Expectancy")
plt.xlabel("life_expectancy")
plt.ylabel("gdp_per_capita")
plt.show()
```


## Figure: Top 10 countries by GDP per capita

```{python}
# label: fig-top10-gdp
# fig-cap: "Top 10 countries by GDP per capita. Source: World Bank WDI (see References)."
# fig-alt: "Bar chart of top 10 countries by GDP per capita"

top10 = df[["country", "gdp_per_capita"]].dropna().sort_values(
    "gdp_per_capita", ascending=False
).head(10)

plt.figure()
plt.bar(top10["country"], top10["gdp_per_capita"])
plt.title("Top 10 Countries by GDP per Capita")
plt.xlabel("Country")
plt.ylabel("GDP per Capita")
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha="right")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```


Task 5
## Table: Key statistics for selected indicators

```{python}
# label: tbl-key-stats
# tbl-cap: "Key statistics for selected indicators. Source: World Bank WDI (see References)."

import numpy as np

indicators = ["gdp_per_capita", "life_expectancy", "inflation_rate"]

desc = df[indicators].describe()  # has: count, mean, std, min, 25%, 50%, 75%, max
median = df[indicators].median(numeric_only=True)

# Add median as its own row, as pandas can't find "median" in the index
desc.loc["median"] = median

stats = desc.loc[["count", "mean", "std", "min", "median", "max"]].round(2)
stats
```


Task 6
As shown in @fig-gdp-life, countries with higher GDP per capita tend to have higher life expectancy.

@fig-top10-gdp highlights how GDP per capita is concentrated among a small set of countries.

Summary statistics are reported in @tbl-key-stats.
